iti109:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti109:2.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso nadiyā sotena ovuyheyya piyarūpasātarūpena.
iti109:2.1.eng: “Suppose a person was being carried along by a river current that seemed nice and pleasant.

iti109:2.2.pli: Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso tīre ṭhito disvā evaṃ vadeyya:
iti109:2.2.eng: If a person with clear eyes saw them, they’d say:

iti109:2.3.pli: ‘kiñcāpi kho tvaṃ, ambho purisa, nadiyā sotena ovuyhasi piyarūpasātarūpena, atthi cettha heṭṭhā rahado saūmi sāvaṭṭo sagaho sarakkhaso yaṃ tvaṃ, ambho purisa, rahadaṃ pāpuṇitvā maraṇaṃ vā nigacchasi maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhan’ti.
iti109:2.3.eng: ‘Worthy man, even though the river current carrying you along seems nice and pleasant, downstream there is a lake with waves and whirlpools, saltwater crocodiles and monsters. When you reach there it will result in death or deadly pain.’

iti109:2.4.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso tassa purisassa saddaṃ sutvā hatthehi ca pādehi ca paṭisotaṃ vāyameyya.
iti109:2.4.eng: Then, when they heard what was said, they’d paddle against the stream using their hands and feet.

iti109:3.1.pli: Upamā kho me ayaṃ, bhikkhave, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
iti109:3.1.eng: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.

iti109:3.3.eng: ‘River current’ is a term for craving.

iti109:4.1.pli: ‘Piyarūpaṃ sātarūpan’ti kho, bhikkhave, channetaṃ ajjhattikānaṃ āyatanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
iti109:4.1.eng: ‘Seeming nice and pleasant’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.

iti109:5.1.pli: ‘Heṭṭhā rahado’ti kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
iti109:5.1.eng: ‘A downstream lake’ is a term for the five lower fetters.

iti109:6.1.eng: ‘Danger of waves’ is a term for anger and distress.

iti109:7.1.eng: ‘Whirlpool’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

iti109:8.1.eng: ‘Saltwater crocodiles and monsters’ is a term for ladies.

iti109:9.1.eng: ‘Against the stream’ is a term for renunciation.

iti109:10.1.pli: ‘Hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyāmo’ti kho, bhikkhave, vīriyārambhassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
iti109:10.1.eng: ‘Paddling with hands and feet’ is a term for rousing energy.

iti109:11.1.pli: ‘Cakkhumā puriso tīre ṭhito’ti kho, bhikkhave, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti.
iti109:11.1.eng: ‘A person with clear eyes’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”

iti109:12.1.eng: “In pain they’d give up sensual pleasures,

iti109:12.2.eng: aspiring to the future sanctuary from the yoke.

iti109:12.3.eng: With deep understanding and heart well freed,

iti109:12.4.comm: The duplicated tattha tattha is not used in a limiting sense such as the English “here and there”, but in a distributive sense, “in each and every place”.

iti109:12.5.eng: That knowledge master <j>who has completed the spiritual journey,

iti109:12.6.eng: and gone to the end of the world, <j>is called ‘one who has gone beyond’.”

iti11:2.1.pli: “Mohaṃ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ tattha cittaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
iti11:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding delusion, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

iti11:2.2.pli: Mohañca kho, bhikkhave, abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ tattha cittaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
iti11:2.2.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding delusion, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.”

iti110:2.1.pli: “Carato cepi, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno uppajjati kāmavitakko vā byāpādavitakko vā vihiṃsāvitakko vā.
iti110:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a mendicant has a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought while walking.

iti110:2.2.pli: Tañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṃ gameti.
iti110:2.2.eng: They tolerate it and don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it. Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when walking.

iti110:2.3.pli: Carampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃbhūto anātāpī anottāpī satataṃ samitaṃ kusīto hīnavīriyoti vuccati.

iti110:3.1.pli: Ṭhitassa cepi, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno uppajjati kāmavitakko vā byāpādavitakko vā vihiṃsāvitakko vā.
iti110:3.1.eng: Suppose a mendicant has a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought while standing …

iti110:3.2.pli: Tañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṃ gameti.

iti110:3.3.pli: Ṭhitopi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃbhūto anātāpī anottāpī satataṃ samitaṃ kusīto hīnavīriyoti vuccati.

iti110:4.1.pli: Nisinnassa cepi, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno uppajjati kāmavitakko vā byāpādavitakko vā vihiṃsāvitakko vā.

iti110:4.2.pli: Tañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṃ gameti.

iti110:4.3.pli: Nisinnopi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃbhūto anātāpī anottāpī satataṃ samitaṃ kusīto hīnavīriyoti vuccati.

iti110:5.1.pli: Sayānassa cepi, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno jāgarassa uppajjati kāmavitakko vā byāpādavitakko vā vihiṃsāvitakko vā.
iti110:5.1.eng: or when lying down while awake.

iti110:5.2.pli: Tañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṃ gameti.
iti110:5.2.eng: They tolerate it and don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it.

iti110:5.3.pli: Sayānopi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jāgaro evaṃbhūto anātāpī anottāpī satataṃ samitaṃ kusīto hīnavīriyoti vuccati.
iti110:5.3.eng: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when lying down while awake.

iti110:6.1.pli: Carato cepi, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno uppajjati kāmavitakko vā byāpādavitakko vā vihiṃsāvitakko vā.

iti110:6.2.pli: Tañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti.
iti110:6.2.eng: They don’t tolerate them, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

iti110:6.3.eng: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘keen and prudent, always energetic and resolute’ when walking.

iti111:2.1.pli: “Sampannasīlā, bhikkhave, viharatha sampannapātimokkhā; pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutā viharatha ācāragocarasampannā aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvino; samādāya sikkhatha sikkhāpadesu.
iti111:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, live by the ethical precepts and the monastic code. Live restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.

iti111:3.1.pli: Sampannasīlānaṃ vo, bhikkhave, viharataṃ sampannapātimokkhānaṃ pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutānaṃ viharataṃ ācāragocarasampannānaṃ aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvīnaṃ samādāya sikkhataṃ sikkhāpadesu, kimassa uttari karaṇīyaṃ?
iti111:3.1.eng: When you’ve done this, what more is there to do?

iti111:4.1.pli: Carato cepi, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno abhijjhā, byāpādo vigato hoti, thinamiddhaṃ vigataṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ vigataṃ hoti, vicikicchā pahīnā hoti, āraddhaṃ hoti vīriyaṃ asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggaṃ.
iti111:4.1.eng: Suppose a mendicant has got rid of desire and ill will while walking, and has given up dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt. Their energy is roused up and unflagging, their mindfulness is established and lucid, their body is tranquil and undisturbed, and their mind is immersed in samādhi and unified.

iti111:4.2.pli: Carampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃbhūto ātāpī ottāpī satataṃ samitaṃ āraddhavīriyo pahitattoti vuccati.
iti111:4.2.eng: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘keen and prudent, always energetic and resolute’ when walking.

iti112:0.3.eng: The Chapter on the Brahmin’s Offering of the Teaching

iti112:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti112:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, the world has been understood by the Realized One;

iti112:2.2.eng: and he is detached from the world.

iti112:2.3.eng: The origin of the world has been understood by the Realized One;

iti112:2.4.eng: and he has given up the origin of the world.

iti112:2.5.eng: The cessation of the world has been understood by the Realized One;

iti112:2.6.eng: and he has realized the cessation of the world.

iti112:2.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of the world has been understood by the Realized One;

iti112:2.8.eng: and he has developed the practice that leads to the cessation of the world.

iti112:3.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā yasmā taṃ tathāgatena abhisambuddhaṃ,
iti112:3.1.eng: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind, all that has been understood by the Realized One.

iti112:3.2.eng: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

iti112:4.1.pli: Yañca, bhikkhave, rattiṃ tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṃ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, yaṃ etasmiṃ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati, sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva hoti no aññathā,
iti112:4.1.eng: From the night when the Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—in the element of extinguishment with no residue—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.

iti112:4.2.eng: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

iti112:5.1.pli: Yathāvādī, bhikkhave, tathāgato tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī,
iti112:5.1.eng: The Realized One does as he says, and says as he does.

iti112:5.3.eng: that’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

iti112:6.1.pli: Sadevake, bhikkhave, loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya tathāgato abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī,
iti112:6.1.eng: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—the Realized One is the vanquisher, the unvanquished, the universal seer, the wielder of power.

iti112:6.2.eng: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.”

iti112:7.3.eng: he is detached from the whole world,

iti112:10.1.eng: That Blessed One is the Buddha,

iti112:10.3.eng: in all the world with its gods,

iti112:11.1.eng: And so those gods and humans,

iti112:12.1.eng: ‘Tamed, he is the best of tamers,

iti14:2.1.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekanīvaraṇampi samanupassāmi yena nīvaraṇena nivutā pajā dīgharattaṃ sandhāvanti saṃsaranti yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, avijjānīvaraṇaṃ.
iti14:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I do not see a single shroud, shrouded by which people wander and transmigrate for a long time like the shroud of ignorance.

iti14:2.2.pli: Avijjānīvaraṇena hi, bhikkhave, nivutā pajā dīgharattaṃ sandhāvanti saṃsarantī”ti.
iti14:2.2.eng: Shrouded by ignorance, people wander and transmigrate for a long time.”

iti15:2.1.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekasaṃyojanampi samanupassāmi yena saṃyojanena saṃyuttā sattā dīgharattaṃ sandhāvanti saṃsaranti yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, taṇhāsaṃyojanaṃ.
iti15:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I do not see a single fetter, fettered by which people wander and transmigrate for a long time like the fetter of craving.

iti15:2.2.pli: Taṇhāsaṃyojanena hi, bhikkhave, saṃyuttā sattā dīgharattaṃ sandhāvanti saṃsarantī”ti.
iti15:2.2.eng: Fettered by craving, people wander and transmigrate for a long time.”

iti15:3.2.eng: as they transmigrate on this long journey.

iti15:3.3.eng: They go from this state to another,

iti15:4.2.eng: that craving is the cause of suffering—

iti15:4.3.eng: rid of craving, free of grasping,

iti15:5.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti15:5.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.

iti16:1.1.eng: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.

iti16:2.1.pli: “Sekhassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno appattamānasassa anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ patthayamānassa viharato ajjhattikaṃ aṅganti karitvā nāññaṃ ekaṅgampi samanupassāmi yaṃ evaṃ bahūpakāraṃ yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasikāro.
iti16:2.1.eng: “Taking into account interior factors, mendicants, I do not see a single one that is so very helpful as rational application of mind for a trainee mendicant who hasn’t achieved their heart’s desire, but lives aspiring to the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

iti16:2.2.pli: Yoniso, bhikkhave, bhikkhu manasi karonto akusalaṃ pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāvetī”ti.
iti16:2.2.eng: A mendicant rationally applying the mind gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful.”

iti16:4.1.pli: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
iti16:4.1.eng: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
